Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing Siriano and Desano to Determine Universal Principles of Language Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A finely balanced linguistic ecology is needed to sustain the practice of linguistic exogamy which ensures that marriage occurs between speakers of different languages. These linguistic ecologies and the languages used to sustain them can begin to breakdown as speakers transition to larger world languages. Siriano and Desano, two languages of Northeastern Amazonia, have traditionally been maintained through linguistic exogamic practices which are now breaking down with the increasing influence of Brazilian Portuguese and Spanish.

Wilson Silva of the Rochester Institute of Technology will undertake a three-year study of Siriano [sir] and Desano [des] before further influence of language contact makes this difficult. These languages exhibit a number of typologically noteworthy features of broad scholarly interest such nasal harmony (where nasality extends over several segments), tone (the use of pitch for meaningful contrasts), noun classifiers (classifying nouns grammatically in terms of universal semantic parameters), and evidentiality (indicating what kinds of evidence are available for a given statement). Research products will include a linguistically annotated database, a reference grammar for Desano, audio and video documentation and preliminary description of Siriano. Silva's research will be useful in reconstructing the genetic relationship among languages of the Vaupés Linguistic Area to which Desano and Siriano belong. Understanding the structures of these closely related languages of the Eastern Tukanoan branch of the Tukanoan family will shed light on the nature of language change through contact with other languages.

This project has strong support from the communities and their leaders, and involves close collaboration between researchers and community members in Colombia and Brazil where these languages are spoken. The corpus of audiovisual and audio recordings collected as a result of this research will be archived at the Archive of the Indigenous Language of Latin America at the University of Texas at Austin and at the Museum of the Indian at National Foundation of the Indian (Museu do Índio at the Fundação Nacional do Índio), Brazil.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to undertake a three-year study of Siriano [sir] and Desano [des], two endangered Tukanoan languages spoken by Indigenous peoples in Brazil and Colombia, before the further influence of language contact with Portuguese and Spanish makes this problematic. Specifically, the project focused on gathering language data to produce a linguistically annotated database, a reference grammar for Desano, audio and video documentation, and a preliminary description of Siriano. These languages exhibit many typologically noteworthy features of broad scholarly interest such as nasal spreading (where nasality extends over several segments within a word), tone (the use of pitch for meaningful contrasts), noun classifiers (classifying nouns grammatically in terms of universal semantic parameters), and evidentiality (indicating what kinds of evidence are available for a given statement).

The NSF grant was initially awarded in 2015 (BCS-1500755) to Dr. Wilson de Lima Silva (Rochester Institute of Technology). The grant was then transferred under a new award number (BCS-1837852) when Dr. Silva started his new position in Linguistics at the University of Arizona in 2018. The audio and video materials, along with several transcriptions and translations, were deposited in two language archives (the California Language Archive at UC Berkeley and the Endangered Language Archive (ELAR) in the U.K.).

As for the grammatical descriptions, a sketch of the Siriano morphology and a sketch of the Siriano sound system was produced as an M.A. thesis by a student in the Native American Languages & Linguistics M.A. Program at the University of Arizona. Several chapters of the Desano grammar have been completed, and a final draft is planned to be available by the end of 2021. In term of language contact, the project provided important data based on naturalistic multilingual interactions among speakers of several Eastern Tukanoan languages that demonstrate that language mixing occur in everyday interactions, in multiple contexts, and notably when speakers are unguarded in their linguistic behavior. These types of language mixing was thought to not occur among these groups. The aspect of the project that focuses on digital animation of traditional story narratives, addressed the need for the inclusion of Indigenous societies in the digital era. The activities focusing on documenting plant names are essential for ethnobotany and understanding the ecological knowledge of Indigenous societies. All these are key components of the process of the group's cultural preservation and continuity.

In terms of brother impact, this NSF grant engaged thirteen undergraduate students from different disciplines (e.g., computer sciences, film and animation, art design, library sciences, anthropology, biology, engineering, and linguistics) in language documentation and linguistics research. It also provided an international fieldwork opportunity to three undergraduates to participate in interdisciplinary linguistic research in Brazil's Amazon region. Students also had the opportunity to present in professional conferences and be co-authors with the P.I. in published papers. This project has provided opportunities for training and professional development to both members of the Desano-Siriano communities who received training on language documentation and the production of several digital animations based on their traditional stories.

This project provided far-reaching benefits, besides the obvious research outcomes listed above. For example, social benefits: it directly benefited speakers of two minority, endangered Indigenous languages, Desano and Siriano, and their goals to preserve their language and culture for the future generations of speakers.
